utterances: And I wonder if that's connected to the sink rule, which is, something could be on a plate and I would reach across and take a bite off my friend's plate without any problem.
But as soon as that touches the sink, somehow, it's gross and it's not touchable anymore.
It goes on the garbage.
Right, exactly.
Yeah.
You know, she's absolutely right, though, that humans do have this intrinsic ability to, sort of, determine in secret what's germy and what's not.
They've done studies that people are more willing to eat cookies off the floor than they are willing to eat cake.
Cake tends to hold more moisture and so it's easier for the cake to get germs even though, as we all know, cake is more delicious than cookies.
It's also a question of - let me ask you, Jennifer.
If you have that hypothetical piece of buttered toast, and by some happy accident, had landed dry side down, would that be…
No.
No?
I would absolutely go for it.
But butter side down, it has - you have to start over.
There you go.
These are very - these are important distinctions of the five-second rule, Jennifer.
Thanks very much.
Sure thing.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Let's talk with - this is Jim(ph).
And Jim's with us from Shelby, North Carolina.
Jim?
Yes.
Hi.
You're on the air.
(Audio gap) caught me with my pants down.
I was rushing to leave the house and making a pastrami sandwich, which is one of my favorites, and I dropped a piece of pastrami on the kitchen floor.
And the dog made it to it at the same time I did.
And the pastrami tore in half.
So the dog ate half and I ate half.
Well, presumably, not - did your half ever touch the dog's mouth?
It kind of tore in half.
But outside of the lip, I mean…
Yeah.
Yeah.
It was outside of his mouth.
But he had a grab on it and I had the other end.
And it tore in half.
So he got half and I got half.
That's interesting.
And was it still delicious?
It was still delicious.
It's my floor.
I mop it.
So…
Jim, thanks very much.
And we hope you feel the same way in 15 minutes.
I'm sure I'll be fine.
All right.
Thanks very much.
Okay.
Thank you.
And that seems to be another experiential rule, Monica, that, you know, people say, I have, you know, I've had this - I mean, I've never got sick before.
Absolutely.
I talked to one man who described eating a box of Raisinets that he accidentally dropped one on the floor.
He found that Raisinet two weeks later and ate it because he figured that because it was in his house, he'd been able to - he knew what went on on that floor.
And there was another of your interview subjects who said, dusty M&Ms fished out of a jacket pocket after who knows how long, perfectly okay.
Absolutely.
I believe her exact words were: It's like finding a forgotten $20 bill in your pocket, if you've ever had that experience.
And her profession was?
Public health generalist, she said to much humiliation.
Here's an a-mail from Stewart(ph) in Minneapolis.
Is there a George Castanza - of course, the ""Seinfeld"" character - rule for grabbing something, say, an eclair from the top of the stuff in the trashcan?
You know, I think that the jury is out on that one.

There seems to be a stigma where once it lands in the garbage can, we somehow think that it's worse than off the floor, even if it's on top of that doily, as George Castanza swears that his eclair was.
Let's go to Rick(ph).
And Rick is with us from Pullman, Washington.
RICK (Caller) Hi, there.
Yeah.
We have both kids and dogs and so we have this problem often.
If it's peanut butter toast and it falls upside down, then it's certainly picked up some dog hair, which you can't see.
Buttered toast upside down maybe didn't pick up any hair, and so it's, maybe, it's going to be okay.
But I think the deal is that if it's within a few seconds then you saw the entire accident transpire, and so you can - you know what happened and you can pick it up and eat it.
But, if, of course, it's - it sat there for a while, who knows what happened in the interim?
So the line of sight rule aspect is - the line of sight corollary, shall we say, that's important to you, Rick?
Yeah.
Oh, I think it's very important to my kids.
They're three and seven, and that counts.
Also, M&Ms are a whole different animal because they have an armor coating.
M&Ms and Skittles…
Right.
…I think, are pretty much, you know…
Impervious, yeah.

We're talking with Monica Hesse of the Washington Post about her article, ""That Dropped Doughnut: How Soon and How Often Will it Come back Up?"" And you're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
E-mail from Sherry(ph) in San Francisco.
I overfilled a glass of really expensive champagne and about a half a glass spilled on the counter.
Did I slurp it up?
Heck, yeah.
That's not even the dropped food rule.
That's the spilled liquid rule.
Sherry(ph) might take that cake on that one.
Yeah.
But…
The dropped cake.
There was a corollary in your article, though, about the more expensive the item, maybe the longer you're willing to stretch that five seconds.
That's absolutely true.
I mean, if you're dropping a truffle on the floor, I'm guessing that you're going to for it faster than you go for a pork rind.
Here's another e-mail.

I would agree with that.
